title: Acceptance and Commitment Therapy for Chronic Pain: An Overview of Systematic Reviews with Meta-Analysis of Randomized Clinical Trials
abstract:
This overview of reviews aimed to summarize the evidence from systematic reviews and metaanalyses of randomized clinical trials of the efficacy of acceptance and commitment therapy (ACT) for adults with chronic pain in relation to pain intensity, pain-related functioning, quality of life, and psychological factors. The Cumulative Index of Nursing and Allied Health Literature (CINAHL), Embase, PsycINFO, PubMed, and the Cochrane Library databases were searched from inception to July 2, 2023. AMSTAR 2 was used to assess the methodological quality of systematic reviews. The overlap among reviews was calculated. Nine reviews comprising 84 meta-analyses of interest were included. At posttreatment, some meta-analyses mainly showed that ACT can reduce depression symptoms, anxiety symptoms, psychological inflexibility, and pain catastrophizing; and can improve mindfulness, pain acceptance, and psychological flexibility. At three-month follow-up, ACT can reduce depression symptoms and psychological inflexibility, as well as improve pain-related functioning and psychological flexibility. At six-month follow-up, ACT can improve mindfulness, pain-related functioning, pain acceptance, psychological flexibility, and quality of life. At six-twelve-month follow-up, ACT can reduce pain catastrophizing and can improve pain-related functioning. Some methodological and clinical issues are identified in the reviews, such as a very high overlap between systematic reviews, the fact that the certainty of the evidence is often not rated and specific details needed to replicate the interventions reviewed are often not reported. Overall, however, randomized clinical trials and systematic reviews show that ACT can improve outcomes related to chronic pain (eg, pain-related functioning). Future systematic reviews should address the methodological and clinical concerns identified here to produce higher-quality findings. 
 Perspective: Despite certain methodological and clinical issues, randomized clinical trials and systematic reviews of ACT appear to show that it can improve outcomes related to chronic pain (eg, psychological factors).

sections.text: T he global prevalence of chronic pain is estimated at 27.5%  63  and its economic costs are substantial. In the United States alone, 1 in 3 people suffer from chronic pain, producing an annual national cost of between $560 and $635 billion in medical costs and lost productivity.  50 The experience of chronic pain is complex because of the multiple biopsychosocial factors it involves.  36 Therefore, interdisciplinary pain management may be the best coping option for patients with chronic pain dealing with a long list of symptoms related to their condition (eg, physical disability).  10 s part of the biopsychosocial management of chronic pain, psychological interventions-specifically cognitivebehavioral therapies (CBT)-have been the topic of many studies and have shown promising results.  16, 33 Acceptance and commitment therapy (ACT) is a form of CBT that relies on psychological flexibility, operant theory, and relational frame theory.  34 ACT emphasizes that improvement of 6 core processes (acceptance, self-as-context, cognitive defusion, present moment, values, and committed action) increases psychological flexibility and helps people engage in meaningful activities even when they are experiencing negative thoughts or emotions (ie, pain catastrophizing).  12 he idea behind ACT is that experiences that cause us pain, fear, grief, loss, or disappointment should not be repressed or ignored since these feelings are part of human life.  12 nstead, by focusing on personal qualities and activities that prove valuable to us and give us purpose (eg, personal growth), we are better equipped to face them.  12, 21 n chronic pain, different clinical trials have shown that ACT can be delivered online or face-to-face and is often applied alone or as part of interdisciplinary pain management.  32, 56 The number of clinical trials assessing the possible benefits of ACT for chronic pain has increased in the last decade, producing, in turn, a plethora of systematic reviews on this topic during the last 5 years.  4, 13, 17, 32, 45, 53, 56 The overview of the systematic reviews presented herein aims to summarize and critically analyze the benefits that ACT may have for pain intensity, pain-related functioning, psychological factors, and quality of life in adults with chronic pain. Overviews can help pain clinicians and researchers detect potential gaps in knowledge and chart future paths for ACT and chronic pain.

sections.title: Methods
sections.text: The preferred reporting items for overviews of reviews statement  18  and the preferred reporting items for systematic reviews and meta-analyses statement for abstracts were followed.  2 The review protocol was prospectively registered on the Open Science Framework:  https://osf.io/948qr .

sections.title: Deviations From the Review Protocol
sections.text: A retrospective check of protocol databases such as PROSPERO, the Open Science Framework, and International Platform of Registered Systematic Review and Meta-analysis Protocols yielded no overviews of systematic reviews similar to the one presented herein. Eligibility criteria: Only systematic reviews with meta-analysis of randomized clinical trials (RCTs) were included. Ultimately, we focused on RCTs since this research design is considered to yield the highest primary research evidence.  44 Eligibility criteria: quality of life and other psychological factors apart from anxiety and depression symptoms (eg, pain catastrophizing) were considered. This gives us a better perspective on the role ACT plays in chronic pain. Data extraction: We extracted information from systematic reviews that applied sensitivity analyses and/or meta-regressions. This step was essential to determine whether the systematic reviews explored possible sources of heterogeneity in their meta-analyses. Data analysis: Although a bibliometric analysis was not conducted, an upset plot was built to illustrate the overlap among systematic reviews.

sections.title: Data Sources and Search Strategy
sections.text: One reviewer (JMC) searched for Cumulative Index of Nursing and Allied Health Literature (CINAHL) (via EBSCOhost), Embase, PsycINFO (via ProQuest), PubMed, and the Cochrane Library from inception until March 28,  2023. The same search strategies were updated until July 2, 2023. The type of document and the language of publication were considered search filters. Only articles published in peer-reviewed journals and written in English or Spanish were considered. One reviewer (CRB) manually checked the list of references for the included systematic reviews. Search strategies for each electronic database are shown in Supplementary file 1.

sections.title: Eligibility Criteria
sections.text:
The eligibility criteria were chosen using the patient, intervention, comparison, outcome, study design framework.  42 nclusion criteria: P: People diagnosed with chronic pain based on the ACTTION-American Pain Society Pain Taxonomy for chronic pain.  15 : ACT delivered alone or jointly with other co-interventions. No restrictions were considered in terms of cointerventions. ACT is a process-based, third-wave CBT based on 6 core processes (acceptance, self as context, cognitive defusion, being present, values, and committed action).  12 No restrictions were considered in terms of the time point effects of ACT (eg, post-treatment, or three-month follow-up).

C: There were no restrictions considering the type of comparator.

O: Psychological factors (eg, depression symptoms), pain (eg, pain intensity or pain sensitivity), pain-related functioning, and quality of life evaluated with self-reported tools (eg, the hospital anxiety and depression scale).

S: Systematic reviews with meta-analysis evaluating RCTs. The definition of a systematic review proposed in the preferred reporting items for overviews of reviews checklist  18  was used for the selection:

A systematic review is a type of study design that uses systematic, reproducible methods to collect data on primary research studies, critically appraises the available research, and synthesizes the findings descriptively or quantitatively. Typically, reviews considered systematic will include a research question, the sources that were searched (using a reproducible search strategy), the inclusion and exclusion criteria, the methods used to select primary studies, assessments of risk of bias in the included primary studies, and information about data analysis and synthesis that allows the results to be reproduced. However, systematic reviews might lack some of these components, for example, risk of bias assessments.

The exclusion criteria were: 1) meta-analyses that did not include at least 2 RCTs; 2) meta-analyses that mixed RCTs and non-RCTs; 3) network meta-analyses that did not provide direct estimates of comparisons of interest; 4) meta-analyses that mixed clinical trials on chronic pain with those focused on other health conditions (eg, other chronic conditions not involving pain); 5) meta-analyses that combined clinical trials in which ACT was delivered alone or jointly with other interventions with clinical trials on interventions other than ACT (eg, mindfulness practice)  20  ; 6) different outcome measures were meta-analyzed jointly without any clear justification (eg, pain acceptance and self-efficacy)  4  ; 7) overviews of systematic reviews; 8) protocols; 9) thesis dissertations and conference proceedings; and 10) abbreviated or previous versions of systematic reviews that were included in this overview.

sections.title: Study Selection
sections.text: One reviewer (CRB) used the Zotero 6.0.9 Citation Management software for the study selection and did a manual check to remove duplicated records  28  before evaluating titles and abstracts. Subsequently, full texts were analyzed when abstracts appeared to meet the criteria or for studies whose abstracts were unavailable.

sections.title: Methodological Quality
sections.text: Two reviewers (CRB and JMS) independently used AMSTAR 2 to analyze the methodological quality of the systematic reviews.  48 AMSTAR 2 has 16 items with rating options of "yes," "partially," or "no." A total of 7 items are recommended as critical domains (items: 2, 4, 7, 9, 11, 13, 15) that affect the overall confidence of a systematic review. This confidence can be classified as high (no weaknesses or one non-critical item), moderate (more than one non-critical item), low (one critical item with or without non-critical items), or critically low (more than one critical item with or without non-critical items).  48 Any disagreement between reviewers was resolved through consensus. The percentage of agreement was calculated by considering the number of items scored the same by both reviewers before pooling the results of their independent evaluations. The reviewers reached an agreement on items they had scored differently.

sections.title: Data Extraction
sections.text: Whenever possible, 1 reviewer (JMS) extracted the following information from the systematic reviews: 1) first author and year of publication; 2) risk of bias assessment, methodological quality, certainty of the evidence, and the presence of sufficient information to replicate the interventions reviewed; 3) the application of sensitivity analyses and/or meta-regressions; 4) the number of RCTs reported in each meta-analysis; 5) chronic pain diagnosis; 6) the type of experimental and comparator intervention; 7) outcome measures; and 8) the overall effect size for each meta-analysis. All systematic reviews reported effect sizes at predetermined time points (eg, post-intervention or six-month followup). Therefore, this was the first option to extract effect sizes. When time points were not used, effect sizes were extracted from other types of subgroup analyses (eg, the type of experimental or comparator group or the type of clinical health condition). Effect sizes were measured in all of the studies included using standardized mean difference (SMD, Cohen's d, or Hedge's g). Effect size was considered small for an SMD up to .49, medium for an SMD of between .50 and .80, and large for an SMD of .80 or higher.  9 Finally, corresponding authors were contacted via e-mail when certain information was unreported or needed to be clarified.

sections.title: Data Synthesis
sections.text:
One reviewer (JMC) drafted the Results section, which summarizes the findings according to the type of outcome. In this context, 4 categories were included: 1) ACT for pain intensity, 2) ACT for pain-related functioning, 3) ACT for quality of life, 4) ACT for psychological factors. The "ACT for psychological factors" category was subdivided by the psychological factors being evaluated: depression symptoms, anxiety symptoms, distress, pain catastrophizing, pain acceptance, psychological flexibility, psychological inflexibility, values-based action, and mindfulness.

A decision was made to include all meta-analyses that evaluated pain-related functioning, pain interference, or physical disability in the same section. These outcomes were measured with self-reported questionnaires such as the work and social adjustment scale, the multi-dimensional pain inventory, the Oswestry disability index, and the pain and impairment relationship scale. Since all fit with "pain-related functioning," this term is used throughout the study to facilitate the interpretation of the results.

The efficacy of ACT was divided into: 1) positive effect when more than 50% of the meta-analyses conducted on a specific outcome and time point (eg, depression symptoms at post-treatment) reported a positive effect in favor of ACT, 2) negative effect when more than 50% of the metaanalyses conducted on a specific outcome and time point showed a lack of effect of ACT when compared to comparison groups, and 3) inconsistent effect when 50% of the meta-analyses conducted on a specific outcome and time point found a positive effect in favor of ACT and 50% of the meta-analyses did not confirm this positive effect.

sections.title: Overlap Between Systematic Reviews
sections.text: In order to evaluate the primary study overlap between systematic reviews, 1 reviewer (JMS) built a matrix of evidence and calculated the corrected covered area (CCA).  38 CCA refers to the area that is covered after removing the studies once they have been counted. The overlap can be classified as slight (CCA 0-5%), moderate (CCA 6-10%), high (CCA 11-15%), or very high (CCA > 15%).  38

sections.title: Upset Plot
sections.text: One reviewer (CGM) developed an upset plot to illustrate the overlap between systematic reviews.  6 This plot shows the number of RCTs for each review and the intersections between them.  6

sections.title: Origami Plots
sections.text: One reviewer (CGM) developed origami plots to illustrate the possible juxtaposition between the outcomes of interest and compare the number of experimental and comparator interventions.  14 All experimental and comparator interventions regardless of the type of chronic pain were included in these plots.

sections.title: Results
sections.text: A total of 359 references were retrieved from the electronic databases, and 12 extra citations were found manually. After removing duplicates, 201 titles and abstracts remained, and 48 studies were ultimately selected for being assessed at full text. Finally, 9 systematic reviews covering 84 meta-analyses of interest were evaluated (Fig  1 ).  13, 17, 23, 29, 32, 45, 53, 55, 62 Supplementary files 2 and 3 list the studies excluded from electronic and manual searches during the full-text analysis. Table  1  shows the characteristics of systematic reviews and the effect size for each meta-analysis. Briefly, 8 out of 9 of these reviews combined different chronic pain diagnoses in their meta-analyses.  17, 23, 29, 32, 45, 53, 55, 62 One systematic review was focused on fibromyalgia.  13 The meta-analyzed outcomes were pain intensity, pain-related functioning, quality of life, and the following psychological factors: depression symptoms, anxiety symptoms, distress, pain catastrophizing, pain acceptance, psychological flexibility, psychological inflexibility, values-based action, and mindfulness. Methodologically, 3 of the 9 reviews used the grading of recommendations assessment, development, and evaluations (GRADE) approach to assess the certainty of the evidence.  13, 45, 62 None of the reviews used the template for intervention description and replication (TIDieR) checklist to evaluate clinical details for the interventions reviewed. Finally, 8 corresponding authors were contacted to request clarifications or additional information  13, 17, 23, 29, 32, 53, 55, 56  but only 4 responded.  13, 17, 53, 56

sections.title: AMSTAR 2
sections.text: The overall methodological quality of all systematic reviews was deemed critically low (Table  2 ). For 8 out of the 9 reviews, AMSTAR item 11 (appropriate methods for statistical combination of the results) could not be checked and AMSTAR item 14 (satisfactory explanation for, and discussion of, any heterogeneity) could not be checked for 8 out of the 9. Furthermore, AMSTAR item 12 (evaluation of the impact of risk of bias in metaanalysis or other synthesis assessments) could not be checked for 7 out of the 9 reviews. The agreement between reviewers was 95.14%.

sections.title: Section 1: ACT for Pain Intensity (Fourteen Meta-analyses)
sections.text: Seven systematic reviews covering a total of fourteen meta-analyses were included.  17, 23, 29, 32, 53, 55, 62 All metaanalyses combined RCTs on different chronic pain diagnoses. The general trend in terms of ACT reducing pain intensity was: 1) inconsistent results at post-treatment,  17, 23, 29, 53, 55, 62  2) ACT had no effect at three-month follow-up,  23  3) ACT had no effect at six-month followup, 23,53 4) ACT had no effect at six-twelve month followup,  62  and 5) ACT had positive effects though time points were not specified.  29, 32 Only 1 systematic review used the GRADE approach to ascertain the certainty of the evidence.  62 As shown in Table  1 , the certainty of the evidence for pain intensity was assessed as very low at post-treatment and at follow-up when ACT was compared to usual care, minimal support, relaxation techniques, group discussion, exercise, and physical therapy.

Section 2: ACT for Pain-Related Functioning (Fifteen Meta-analyses)
sections.text:
Seven systematic reviews covering a total of 15 metaanalyses were included.  13, 17, 23, 32, 53, 55, 62 Moderate evidence was found that ACT improved pain-related functioning in fibromyalgia at post-treatment and three-six-month follow-up.  13 The rest of the meta- analyses combined RCTs on different chronic pain diagnoses. The general trend in terms of ACT improving pain-related functioning was: 1) inconsistent results at post-treatment,  17, 23, 53, 55, 62  2) ACT had positive effects at three-month follow-up,  23  3) ACT had positive effects at six-month follow-up, 23,53 4) ACT had positive effects at Table 2. Note: Answers: red color: No, yellow color: Partially yes, green color: Yes. Overall Score: CLQR: Critically Low-Quality Review. Items: AMSTAR 1: Did the research questions and inclusion criteria for the review include the components of PICO? AMSTAR 2: Did the report of the review contain an explicit statement that the review methods were established prior to the conduct of the review and did the report justify any significant deviations from the protocol? AMSTAR 3: Did the review authors explain their election of the study designs for inclusion in the review? AMSTAR 4: Did the review authors use a comprehensive literature search strategy? AMSTAR 5: Did the review authors perform study selection in duplicate? AMSTAR 6: Did the review authors perform data extraction in duplicate? AMSTAR 7: Did the review authors provide a list of excluded studies and justify the exclusions? AMSTAR 8: Did the review authors describe the included studies in adequate detail? AMSTAR 9: Did the review authors use a satisfactory technique for assessing the risk of bias in individual studies that were included in the review? AMSTAR 10: Did the review authors report on the sources of funding for the studies included in the review? AMSTAR 11: If meta-analysis was performed did the review authors use appropriate methods for statistical combination of results? AMSTAR 12: If meta-analysis was performed, did the review authors assess the potential impact of risk of bias in individual studies on the results of the meta-analysis or other evidence synthesis? AMSTAR 13: Did the review authors account for the risk of bias in individual studies when interpreting/ discussing the results of the review? AMSTAR 14: Did the review authors provide a satisfactory explanation for, and discussion of, any heterogeneity observed in the results of the review? AMSTAR 15: If they performed quantitative synthesis did the review authors carry out an adequate investigation of publication bias (small study bias) and discuss its likely impact on the results of the review? AMSTAR 16: Did the review authors report any potential sources of conflict of interest, including any funding they received for conducting the review?

sections.title: Section 3: ACT for Quality of Life (Eight Meta-analyses)
sections.text: Four systematic reviews covering a total of 8 metaanalyses were included.  23, 29, 32, 55 All meta-analyses combined RCTs on different chronic pain diagnoses. The general trend in terms of ACT improving quality of life was: 1) inconsistent results at post-treatment,  23, 55  2) ACT had no effect at three-month follow-up,  23  3) ACT had positive effects at six-month follow-up,  23  and 4) ACT had positive effects though time point effects were not specified.  29, 32 The certainty of the evidence was not assessed (Table  1 ). Experimental and comparator interventions are shown in Table  3  and origami plots (Fig  3 ).

sections.title: Section 4: ACT for Psychological Factors (Forty-seven Meta-analyses)
sections.text: This is the only section where the results are grouped into different subsections to account for the multiple psychological factors in the meta-analyses. The subsections correspond to depression symptoms, anxiety symptoms, distress, pain catastrophizing, pain acceptance, psychological flexibility, psychological inflexibility, values-based action, and mindfulness.

sections.title: ACT for Depression Symptoms (Thirteen Meta-analyses)
sections.text:
Six systematic reviews covering a total of 13 metaanalyses were included.  17, 23, 29, 32, 53, 55 All meta-analyses combined RCTs on different chronic pain diagnoses. The overall general trend in terms of ACT reducing depression symptoms was: 1) ACT had positive effects at post- treatment,  17, 23, 29, 53, 55  2) ACT had positive effects at three-month follow-up,  23  3) ACT had no effect at sixmonth follow-up,  23, 53  and 4) ACT had positive effects though time point effects were not specified.  29, 32 The certainty of the evidence was not assessed (Table  1 ).

Experimental and comparator interventions are shown in Table  3  and origami plots (Fig  3 ).

sections.title: ACT for Anxiety Symptoms (Twelve Meta-analyses)
sections.text: Six systematic reviews covering a total of 12 meta-analyses were included.  17, 23, 29, 32, 53, 55 All meta-analyses combined RCTs on different chronic pain diagnoses. The general trend in terms of ACT reducing anxiety symptoms was: 1) ACT had positive effects at post-treatment,  17, 23, 29, 53, 55  2) ACT had no effect at three-month follow-up,  23  3) ACT had no effect at six-month follow-up,  23, 53  and 4) ACT had positive effects though time point effects were not specified.  29, 32 The certainty of the evidence was not assessed (Table  1 ). Experimental and comparator interventions are shown in Table  3  and origami plots (Fig  3) .

sections.title: ACT for Distress (Three Meta-analyses)
sections.text: One systematic review covering a total of 3 metaanalyses was included.  62 All meta-analyses combined RCTs evaluating different chronic pain diagnoses. The general trend in terms of ACT reducing distress, based on the combination of anxiety plus depression, was: 1) ACT had no effect at post-treatment,  62  and 2) ACT had no effect at six-twelve-month follow-up.  62 As shown in Table  1 , the certainty of the evidence was very low at post-treatment and at follow-up when ACT was compared to usual care, minimal support, relaxation techniques, group discussion, exercise, and physical therapy. Experimental and comparator interventions are shown in Table  3  and origami plots (Fig  3) .

sections.title: ACT for Pain Catastrophizing (Five Metaanalyses)
sections.text: Two systematic reviews covering a total of 5 meta-analyses were included.  17, 45 All meta-analyses combined RCTs on different chronic pain diagnoses. The general trend in terms of ACT reducing pain catastrophizing was: 1) ACT had positive effects at post-treatment  17, 45  and 2) ACT had positive effects at six-twelve-month follow-up.  45 Only 1 systematic review used the GRADE approach to ascertain the certainty of the evidence.  45 As shown in Table  1 , the certainty of the evidence for pain catastrophizing was assessed as low at post-treatment and at follow-up when ACT was compared to usual care, expressive writing interventions, or wait-list whereas the certainty of the evidence was assessed as high at post-treatment and at follow-up when ACT was compared to active controls. Experimental and comparator interventions are shown in Table  3  and origami plots (Fig  3) .

sections.title: ACT for Pain Acceptance (Six Metaanalyses)
sections.text: Three systematic reviews covering a total of 6 metaanalyses were included.  23, 32, 53 All meta-analyses combined RCTs on different chronic pain diagnoses. The general trend in terms of ACT improving pain acceptance was: 1) ACT had positive effects in favor of ACT at post-treatment,  23, 53  2) ACT had positive effects at sixmonth follow-up,  23, 53  and 3) ACT had positive effects though time point effects were not specified.  32 The certainty of the evidence was not assessed (Table  1 ). Experimental and comparator interventions are shown in Table  3  and origami plots (Fig  3 ).

sections.title: ACT for Psychological Flexibility (Two Meta-analyses)
sections.text: Two meta-analyses combining RCTs on different chronic pain diagnoses showed ACT had positive effects at post-treatment  53  and six-month follow-up for improving psychological flexibility.  53 The certainty of the evidence was not assessed (Table  1 ). Experimental and comparator interventions are shown in Table  3  and origami plots (Fig  3 ).

sections.title: ACT for Psychological Inflexibility (Two Meta-analyses)
sections.text: Two meta-analyses combining RCTs on different chronic pain diagnoses showed ACT had positive effects at post-treatment  23  and three-month follow-up for reducing psychological inflexibility.  23 The certainty of the evidence was not assessed (Table  1 ). Experimental and comparator interventions are shown in Table  3  and origami plots (Fig  3 ).

sections.title: ACT for Values-based Action (Two Metaanalyses)
sections.text: Two meta-analyses combining RCTs on different chronic pain diagnoses showed ACT had no effect either at post-treatment or six-month follow-up.  53 The certainty of the evidence was not assessed (Table  1 ). Experimental and comparator interventions are shown in Table  3  and origami plots (Fig  3 ).

sections.title: ACT for Mindfulness (Two Metaanalyses)
sections.text: Two meta-analyses combining RCTs on different chronic pain diagnoses showed ACT had positive effects on improving mindfulness at post-treatment and sixmonth follow-up.  53 The certainty of the evidence was not assessed (Table  1 ). Experimental and comparator interventions are shown in Table 3 and origami plots (Fig 3).

sections.title: Discussion
sections.text: This overview of systematic reviews aimed to summarize ACT's potential for effectively addressing chronic pain. At post-treatment, meta-analyses mainly showed a reduction of depression symptoms, anxiety symptoms, psychological inflexibility, and pain catastrophizing as well as an improvement in mindfulness, pain acceptance, and psychological flexibility. At three-month follow-up, ACT was shown to reduce depression symptoms and psychological inflexibility and to improve pain-related functioning and psychological flexibility. At six-month follow-up, ACT improved mindfulness, pain-related functioning, pain acceptance, psychological flexibility, and quality of life. At sixtwelve-month follow-up, ACT was shown to reduce pain catastrophizing and improve pain-related functioning. A recent overview of systematic reviews has also found that ACT could reduce anxiety and depression symptoms in different clinical populations (eg, patients with cancer or multiple sclerosis)  5  which may support these findings. While these results should encourage pain clinicians to consider ACT when treating patients with chronic pain, the clinical and methodological issues cited below should be considered when interpreting the findings of our overview.

sections.title: Clinical and Methodological Considerations
sections.text:
As occurs in many areas of health research, studies on ACT are often characterized by heterogeneity, inadequate initial reporting in trials, unsatisfactory approaches to bias and quality, and idiosyncratic outcome categories. In terms of the systematic reviews included here, the GRADE approach  44  to rate the certainty of the evidence was missing in 6 out of the 9 reviews.  17, 23, 29, 32, 53, 55 When systematic reviews are done without this tool, it is impossible to know how a potential risk of bias, inconsistencies, indirect evidence, imprecise results, and publication bias could affect the quality of the findings. There were, however, 3 systematic reviews that applied the GRADE approach: Du et al  13  found moderate evidence of ACT improving pain-related functioning for fibromyalgia. Schütze et al  45  found high evidence of ACT reducing pain catastrophizing when compared to active controls with different chronic pain diagnoses, though evidence was low when ACT was compared to usual care, wait-list, or expressive writing interventions, and Williams et al  62  found very low evidence for the efficacy of ACT on pain, pain-related functioning, and distress. Overall, based on the information in the RCTs and ACT reviews, it appears that ACT can improve outcomes related to chronic pain (eg, pain-related functioning), although the certainty of this evidence has not been broadly checked. Therefore, systematic reviewers in the field of ACT and chronic pain are strongly encouraged to use the GRADE approach to confirm the grade of certainty of the findings observed.

Overall, the systematic reviews included here showed that ACT could improve pain-related functioning, psychological factors, and quality of life at different time points. However, pain clinicians should be aware that different forms of delivering ACT (face-to-face, online, self-help books, individual sessions, or group sessions) were combined in some of the meta-analyses.  13, 23, 32, 62 nce sufficient data is available, it will be important for future studies to examine the effect size of each modality and pose the question as to whether or not a combination of modalities affects the estimation of the effect size.

Furthermore, some chronic pain diagnoses such as chronic headache, chronic low back pain, fibromyalgia, or mixed chronic pain were combined in some meta-analyses.  32 Although different chronic pain diagnoses may share similar characteristics in their progression and perpetuation, the use of secondary analyses such as metaregressions may help determine whether the combination of different pain diagnoses in the same meta-analysis influences the overall effect size.

sections.title: Future Research
sections.text: In order to improve quality, future systematic reviews could use the TIDieR checklist  22  to evaluate the clinical details for the interventions reviewed. This checklist is based on 12 items that can be rated as 'reported,' 'partially reported' or 'not reported' to collect information on aspects of the intervention such as who provided, how and where, what material and procedures, and adherence details. In addition, the GRADE approach should be used to assess the certainty of the evidence of each meta-analyzed outcome. Secondary analyses such as meta-regressions, subgroup meta-analyses, or sensitivity analyses could be also helpful in detecting possible sources of heterogeneity. Finally, future systematic reviews with meta-analysis should summarize evidence on ACT with regard to a specific chronic pain diagnosis (eg, neck pain or knee pain) whenever it is available.

sections.title: Limitations
sections.text: Some systematic reviews may have been overlooked due to the exclusion of thesis dissertations, conference proceedings, and systematic reviews with meta-analyses published in languages other than English or Spanish. Cochrane recommends that 2 independent reviewers conduct screening and inclusion, methodological quality/ risk of bias assessments, and data extraction in overviews of reviews.  41 However, the Cochrane recommendation for screening and inclusion or data extraction was not followed here, which could increase the chance of bias in our methodological process. Only AMSTAR 2 was applied to assess the methodological quality of systematic reviews. As AMSTAR 2 and the ROBIS tool  58  overlap in many signaling questions,  37  the ROBIS tool was not used in this overview. The results were not divided into categories by the type of comparison group. Although there were meta-analyses comparing ACT versus passive or active comparison groups, some meta-analyses mixed passive and active comparison groups in the same analysis, and some meta-analyses did not specify what comparison groups were mete-analyzed (See Table  1  for all comparisons). Therefore, we did not separate those meta-analyses that analyzed the efficacy of ACT versus passive controls (eg, wait list) from those meta-analyses that evaluated the efficacy of ACT versus active controls (eg, other psychological intervention).

sections.title: Conclusions
sections.text: In the last decade, a great number of RCTs and reviews have demonstrated that ACT can be effectively used for chronic pain. Despite the methodological and clinical issues detected in many of the systematic reviews, the evidence appears to indicate that ACT improves outcomes related to chronic pain (eg, psychological factors). Most of the systematic reviews show that ACT can reduce depression symptoms, anxiety symptoms, psychological inflexibility, and pain catastrophizing and that it can improve mindfulness, pain-related functioning, pain acceptance, psychological flexibility, and quality of life at different time points. Finally, as noted herein, systematic reviewers should be encouraged to apply the GRADE approach to confirm the grade of the certainty of their findings.
